bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, April 19, 1928

div1.p: Carter reports that she is working steadily on the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever and is preparing to work at the Library of Congress to track down bibliographic references.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, April 19, 1928

The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
April 19, 1928
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
This is just to tell you that I am working along steadily,
and satisfactorily, on the History of Yellow Fever, from four to
four and a half hours a day.

Father's rough bibliographic notes are proving very valuable
as they supply many titles of books: first names of authors and dates,
omitted, for the sake of continuity[unclear], in the book, but very necessary
for our bibliography. These bibliographic notes are neither so involved
nor so extensive (indeed I wish they were more extensive!) as were the
inserts for the revised copy of the book. They are, however, suffi-
ciently hard to handle, being written, in pencil, on all sorts and
sizes of paper, in blank books, occasionally on the backs of reprints
etc. etc. Also they are not always easy to decipher. I have, however,
almost finished them, hope to do so next week, and feel that the time
spent on them will have justified itself many times over in the addition-
al number of complete references we shall have available for checking
at the two Libraries here. I have not yet gotten an assistant as I
feel that until I have gotten everything possible from the above notes
I can do better work alone. Indeed, anyone not trained to Father's
-2-
Father's
methods of work (and chairography!) would be decidedly in the way. at
present.

I have an appointment day after to-morrow morning, however, with
Mr. Putnam, of the Library of Congress, when I shall take up the matter
of working facilities at the Library and of the possibility of getting
a part-time assistant, conversant, if possible, with Spanish and Por-
tuguese. I am contemplating beginning taking the Library of Congress
first, because it is the hardest part of the checking--the books there
containing most of the references in old Spanish, Portuguese, Maya etc.
which it is most advisable that I clear up personally. The work at
the Library of the Surgeon General, while tedious, should be--compara-
tively--“plain sailing.”

I think I am slowly improving physically, not perceptibly
from day to day, but there does seem a gain from week to week. I
saw Dr. Thayer last Saturday and Dr. Minor, of Washington, says he
wishes to see me once a week while I am here. You can see then, that
I am taking all possible precautions “to hold out” until the end of
the work.

Hoping to have the pleasure of seeing you when next you are
in Washington, I remain
div1.closer:
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter The Rockefeller Foundation,
Dr. Frederick F. Russell,
Director,
International Health Division,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
